summary: This document is a chain of email correspondence from March to June 2019, primarily between federal prosecutors and an approver, requesting and granting travel permission for the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein (case 2018R01618). The travel is for conducting victim interviews and meetings in Los Angeles, West Palm Beach, and Fort Lauderdale.

connections.description: They are part of the same investigation team, traveling together to conduct victim interviews and meetings for the Epstein case.

events.title: Initial Travel Request for Florida Meetings
events.description: Assistant U.S. Attorney 'S' requests permission to travel to West Palm Beach and/or Fort Lauderdale, Florida, for two days of meetings and interviews related to the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Travel Approval for Florida Trip
events.description: Travel request for 'S' and another individual to go to West Palm Beach, Florida, for approximately three days for meetings and interviews in the Epstein case is approved.

events.title: Travel Request for Florida Victim Interviews
events.description: Request for permission to travel to West Palm Beach, Florida, for approximately three days to conduct victim interviews, with the team potentially including 'S', 'M', and another individual.

events.title: Travel Request for Los Angeles Victim Interview
events.description: Request for permission to travel to Los Angeles for a victim interview, with the team being some combination of 'S', 'M', and/or another individual as previously.

keyFacts: The document references the federal criminal case 'United States v. Epstein, 2018R01618', described as an investigation relating to enticement of minors for sexual activity.
Federal prosecutors from the Southern District of New York were actively conducting victim interviews in multiple cities (Los Angeles, West Palm Beach, Fort Lauderdale) in the spring of 2019.
The travel requests indicate a pattern of needing to reserve hotel conference rooms specifically for conducting victim interviews.
The correspondence shows internal bureaucratic processes (travel approvals) within the U.S. Attorney's office for the Epstein investigation.
The investigation was ongoing and active from at least March to June 2019, involving a team of prosecutors and investigators.
